body.head: Events of the Month of February.
body.p: The close of February and the first week of March 1851, are replete with interest, and mark a fresh epoch in the fast changing history of our eventful sojourn in the Northern Regions

The arrival of the Sun in our heavens, was we may say commemorated by the Fancy Dress Ball_ of it we have elsewhere spoken. Hardly had our daylight extende itself to the length of ten hours, when Mr Hamilton & Dr Bradford with a Sledge, & a party of Seamen, performed a pedestrian feat by walking to the Expeditions. Scene from the Pantomime of 'Zero' wintering under Cornwallis Island, and we rejoiced ot see them returned with some of our gallant friends who kindly came over to pay us a visit, & merriment in their little Society as well as our own.

The 'Assistance' had made arrangements to celebrate the anniversary of our Expedition having been put into commission by a performance on the boards of the Royal Arctic Theatre, unhappily a very severe gale of wind prevented this thier intention, being carried into effect, and the performance as well as the closing of the Theatre was unavoidably postponed to the 4th of March.
On that Evening a crowded house proved how unabated was the interest fled in a Stage which has been a source of great amusement throughout the Squadron Scene from Charles XII.

Not small are the obligations which the non performers labour under to the many individuals who have in such divers manners tended to the general amusement. Managers, Actors, Painters, Prompters, and Scene Shifters,

"Nobly each & all their means have used" as the neat Epilogue truthfully says_ ans the result has been a Theatre unequalled in excellence by any Squadron, & reflecting no small credit on the 'Assistances' in general_ especially when it be remembered that the performances have taken place on the Upper Deck with the external temperature as low as 30Â° below zero.

The Original Pantomime of Zero, was again performed, and had been evidently much improved. A new Song or two was introduced & the indefatigable Mr Dean astonished the Audience by his clever imitation of a Bear & a Fox.

A witty & highly diverting explanation of the figures exhibited by a Magic Lanthorn next followed in rapid succession and as the Family Herald would say "we were constantly thrown into a sweet agony of joy & sorrow," by the sudden transition from the burning of Hindov Widows, to the bombardment of Jean d'Acre.

The pretty drama of Charles the 12th with the following Cast of Characters:_
Charles XII,___Lt Mecham.
Major Vauberg,___Captn Ommanney
Adam Brock,___Mr Ede
Triptolemus Muddlewerk,___Mr Krabbe
Gustavus de Mervelt,___Mr Markham
Colonel Reichil,___Mr May
General Duckerst,___Lt Cator
Officers,___Messre Richards&Shellabeer
Women Eudiga___Mr McDougall
Ulrica___M Pearse
closed the Evening's entertainment._ From the Royal Swede to the Officer of the Guard, all the parts were admirably sustained. Adam Brock was as like as the original as the imagination could picture it, and the worthy Burgomaster kept the Company in roard of laughter._ Firman looked the picture of conscious innocence, and appeared fully alive to the fact that altho innocent, he might yet be drawn & quartered for Royal pleasure or Stage effect.

Oh!for a Crowgwill to tell of the facinating performance of Eudiga & Ulrica. England's fiar daughters would have seen the truthful representationof the loves of Ulrica & Gustavus de Mervelt, or Eudiga & Colnl Richel.

Where the young ladies could possibly have aquired the subtle knowledge they displayed in the woeful intricacy of female attire, we know not, suffice it, that not a point was missing._ As a finale the Manager delivered,
The following Epilouge,
from the pen of Mr Ede._
When first this Curtain rose, we strove to say,
All our sucess in your applause would lay.
Thus trusting we have tried, & not in vain,
To hear your laughter o'er & o'er again.
One sole regret we had, until to night,
That those so near, could not with us unite;
And in this mimic world, the hourse beguile,
Where all must feel the want od woman's smile.
But now 'tis o'er, the flow'r of day expands,
And greedy time new sacrifice demands.
The strength of youth, the wisdom of the sage.
Must soon appear upon life's boundless stage.
Amusement then to duty will give place,
And lines of thought will mark the anxious face,
In merriment & fun we've joinged together,
Defying coul & every change of weather.
Nobly each and all their means have used,
First the Amusers, then in turn the Amused,
In health & happiness the time has fled;
And bright success on all, its rays has shed.
That our next efforts may as well succeed,
Is the great wish in which we're all agreed.

The Curtain then dropped amidst the loud cheets of a delighted audience, and thus concluded the performacnes of the Royal Arctic Theatre. A supper & Refereshment, were as usual hospitably provide by the 'Jolly Assistances', to which right good justice was done by Scene from Charles XII. Midnight the time consuming gaities of out Arctic Winter had passed away and we rose on the morrow, to look forward and prepare for the great & glorious labour before us.
